award: CESAB synthesis centre to ACTIAS project

abstract: <jats:p>The genus <jats:italic>Lonomia</jats:italic> Walker, 1855 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) is of particular interest to the medical community, since the scoli of these caterpillars harbor a venom that induces hemorrhaging in humans. In Colombia, deadly encounters with <jats:italic>Lonomia achelous</jats:italic> (Cramer, 1777), have been reported since 2000. There is little information on the main biological and ecological aspects of this genus to help better understand and develop prevention strategies. This study aimed to describe morphological and biological aspects (especially of immature stages) of four recently reported species of <jats:italic>Lonomia</jats:italic> in Colombia that pose a risk to humans. We collected caterpillars and adults from five localities and reared them under laboratory conditions. Specimens were identified using DNA barcoding and dissection of adult male genitalia. We provided the first description, to our knowledge, of part of the life cycles of <jats:italic>Lonomia casanarensis</jats:italic> Brechlin, 2017 and <jats:italic>Lonomia orientoandensis</jats:italic> Brechlin & Meister, 2011 and the complete life cycles of <jats:italic>Lonomia columbiana</jats:italic> Lemaire, 1972 and <jats:italic>Lonomia orientocordillera</jats:italic> Brechlin, Käch & Meister, 2013. We also present the first records of the parasitoids of <jats:italic>L</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>orientocordillera</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>L</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>casanarensis</jats:italic> and new host plants. This information will guide not only their morphological recognition and the identification of their parasitoids and hosts, but also will guide rearing methods of these and other <jats:italic>Lonomia</jats:italic> species in new studies to prevent incidents with humans and create specific antivenoms.</jats:p>
title: Characterization of morphological and biological aspects of venomous caterpillars of the genus Lonomia Walker (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) in Colombia
